Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Measuring Tidal Inundation Regime with Temperature Loggers in Mangrove Habitat

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Inundation regime is a dominant environmental factor controlling the ecology and physical environment of tidal and riparian wetlands (Amlin and Rood 2001; Gilman et al. 2008). Due to the spatial constraints from local variability of modeling estuarine inundation regimes with traditional equipment (e.g. water level loggers), a new method was developed to test the feasibility of using a low-cost method to monitor inundation regime at higher spatial resolution.

The Temperature Sensor Method for detecting tidal inundation regime is based on the principle that air temperature responds more rapidly than water to solar warming. Therefore, an inundation event occurring during the warmest daytime hours should be signaled by a sharp decrease in temperature relative to air temperature upon inundation and a nighttime inundation event (or one during cooler daytime hours relative to the water temperature) should be signaled by a sharp increase in temperature relative to air temperature. This method was first validated in Oregon estuaries over a two year period (Brophy et al. 2010). For broader application of the method, testing in other climates was needed. The purpose of this study was to test the Temperature Sensor Method in Chinese mangrove swamps, since restoration projects could potentially benefit from using this low-cost method for determining inundation regime at specific sites. Dongzhiagang Reserve, Shankou Reserve and Zhangjiangkou Reserve were selected for testing the method based on their locations along the latitudinal range of naturally occurring mangroves in China. Results reinforced the signal characteristics seen in Oregon, but the daytime inundation signals were generally more evident than they had been in Oregon. On average, temperature signals of inundation at the three reserves were weaker during the daytime (1.8°±0.8°C) than nighttime signals (3.5°±1.6°C). The magnitude of temperature change during nighttime inundation and emersion events likely varied according to tidal cycle, temporal proximity to daytime solar warming, and estuarine physical environment. This study suggests that the Temperature Sensor Method is a valuable tool for detecting tidal inundation regime in two geographic settings and has the potential for wider application.
